0.body: Welcome to our humble abode. The thing you're seeing is Bot Designer for Discord 's wiki. If you're curious about functions please feel free to visit this section .
0.title: Foreword

1.body: Note that we often forget to update this article, so some stuff is missing.
1.title: Changelog

10.body: Fixed disappearing bot status Fixed $serverCount in bot status Improved caching Functions that require privileged intents are now marked accordingly Added $getLeaderboardValue[] Added $awaitReactions[] Awaited commands are now available for everyone Added awaited reactions Fixed problems with DMs
10.title: November

100.body: setResponse(replyText) where replyText is a string value. This command will send message to the channel from which command was used. setEmbedResponse(title, description, footer) where title, description, footer are string values. This command will send embedded message to the channel from which command was used. setEmbedImage(imageURL) where imageURL is a string value. This command sets image of the embedded message. imageURL has to point to the direct url of the image. ban(userID) where userID is a string value. banWithReason(userID, reason) where userID and reason are the string value. unban(userID) where userID is a string value. kick(userID) where userID is a string value. kickWithReason(userID, reason) where userID and reason are the string value. giveRole(userID, roleID) where userID and roleID are the string value. This command gives the role to the user. takeRole(userID, roleID) where userID and roleID are the string value. This command takes the role from the user. channelTyping() Shows "Bot is typing..." message createChannel(name, type) where name and type are the string values. type value can be either equal to "text" or "voice". Providing wrong type will result in throwing an exception which you can catch. removeChannel(chanID) where chanID is a string value. pinMessage(channelID, messageID) where channelID and messageID are the string values. unpinMessage(channelID, messageID) where channelID and messageID are the string values. sendChannelMessage(channelID, message) where channelID and messageID are the string values. Sends message to the provided channel.
100.title: Currently supported API functions:

101.body: Bot Designer for Discord allows you to use JavaScript (ES2015) . Discord's API is not fully supported yet but there will be more extensive support in the future. (NOTE: Callbacks don't support JavaScript at the moment)
101.title: JavaScript

102.body: message - string value. It contains message written by the user. commandPrefix - string value. It contains name of the used command. authorId - string value. It contains ID of the user that executed that command. channelId - string value. It contains ID of the channel where the command was used. userMentions - array of string values. It contains user mentions (pings) . roleMentions - array of string values. It contains role mentions (pings) .
102.breadcrumbs: JavaScript » Introduction » Available objects in the commands:
102.title: Available objects in the commands:

103.body: setResponse(replyText) where replyText is a string value. This command will send message to the channel from which command was used. setEmbedResponse(title, description, footer) where title, description, footer are string values. This command will send embedded message to the channel from which command was used. setEmbedImage(imageURL) where imageURL is a string value. This command sets image of the embedded message. imageURL has to point to the direct url of the image. ban(userID) where userID is a string value. banWithReason(userID, reason) where userID and reason are the string value. unban(userID) where userID is a string value. kick(userID) where userID is a string value. kickWithReason(userID, reason) where userID and reason are the string value. giveRole(userID, roleID) where userID and roleID are the string value. This command gives the role to the user. takeRole(userID, roleID) where userID and roleID are the string value. This command takes the role from the user. channelTyping() Shows "Bot is typing..." message createChannel(name, type) where name and type are the string values. type value can be either equal to "text" or "voice". Providing wrong type will result in throwing an exception which you can catch. removeChannel(chanID) where chanID is a string value. pinMessage(channelID, messageID) where channelID and messageID are the string values. unpinMessage(channelID, messageID) where channelID and messageID are the string values. sendChannelMessage(channelID, message) where channelID and messageID are the string values. Sends message to the provided channel.

104.body: (for premium bots) Thanks to awaited reactions your bot can be triggered by reactions end result Here's how the end result looks like.
104.title: Awaited reactions

105.body: accept command $awaitReactions[awaited reaction name;reaction] is used to specify which command is used when user reacts with reaction. $awaitReactions[] allows you to group reactions (as you can see in the accept command) by specifing more awaited reaction names and reactions. What does it mean? When one of the reactions is used then the other one stops working. So for example if I react with ✔️ then ❌ stops working.
105.title: accept command

106.body: Here you can see the acceptCmd and declineCmd awaited reaction commands: acceptCmd acceptCmd $reaction[name]. As you can see it's pretty straightforward. If you want to know what emoji was used in the $reaction[] trigger command then you can use $usedEmoji which will return the emoji that was used.
106.title: Awaited reaction trigger

107.body: (for premium bots) Thanks to awaited reactions your bot can be triggered by reactions end result Here's how the end result looks like.
107.title: Awaited reactions

108.body: accept command $awaitReactions[awaited reaction name;reaction] is used to specify which command is used when user reacts with reaction. $awaitReactions[] allows you to group reactions (as you can see in the accept command) by specifing more awaited reaction names and reactions. What does it mean? When one of the reactions is used then the other one stops working. So for example if I react with ✔️ then ❌ stops working.
108.title: accept command

109.body: Here you can see the acceptCmd and declineCmd awaited reaction commands: acceptCmd acceptCmd $reaction[name]. As you can see it's pretty straightforward. If you want to know what emoji was used in the $reaction[] trigger command then you can use $usedEmoji which will return the emoji that was used.
109.breadcrumbs: Premium » Awaited Reactions » Awaited reaction trigger
109.title: Awaited reaction trigger

Hello World!

116.body: (for premium bots) $messageContains[] is a callback that allows you to create a trigger with multiple phrases. In addition, the bot also looks for those phrases anywhere in the author's message. This feature is great for creating a auto-response or auto-moderation system.
116.title: $messageContains

118.body: phrase1 - The first phrase the bot checks for. phrase2/etc - You can add multiple phrases if you would like. These fields are optional.
118.title: Breakdown

119.body: a. Make the command trigger $messageContains[] b. Put text in the reply message/code image Now, let's say in chat someone typed: Hello Bot!, Hello, Hey Everyone!, Hi Noituri, etc. The bot would respond with "Hello there! How are you?".

12.title: September

120.body: Callbacks are commands for triggers which are executed when a certain action is preformed. These actions include banning, unbanning, user joining, user leaving, etc. Callbacks are not used in the command code, they are used in the command trigger. This section will explain the callbacks you can use.
120.title: Callbacks

121.body: Callbacks are commands for triggers which are executed when a certain action is preformed. These actions include banning, unbanning, user joining, user leaving, etc. Callbacks are not used in the command code, they are used in the command trigger. This section will explain the callbacks you can use.
121.title: Callbacks

122.body: When a user joins the server, the bot sends a message.
122.title: $onJoined

123.body: a. Make the command trigger $onJoined[CHANNEL ID]. image b. Input your code/reply text. image (4) c. Now you have a welcome message! image (5)
123.title: Example: $onJoined

124.body: Is $onJoined bugged or not working? You must have at least version 1.17.9 of the app. Go to Discord Developer Portal open your bot page and enable member intents. image image Open app and go to bot settings then enable member intents. image image image Note: Enabled intents in the app should reflect the intents enabled in Discord's dashboard. For example: If you have members intent enabled in Discord's dashboard then you should respectively enable them in the app (unless you don't want to use them at all) . Make sure $onJoined[CHANNEL ID] is inputted in the 'command trigger' field. image Note: Channel IDs are not channel names! Provide a channel ID ! Make sure your bot has permission to speak in the channel provided in $onJoined[].
124.title: Troubleshooting

125.body:
Both free and premium users can use $onJoined[]. Also, all users can put $getServerVar[] within $onJoined[]. However, free users can not use $getServerVar[] outside of callbacks. If you own a global bot and want to make it so multiple different servers can use $onJoined[]. Follow these steps: 1: Make a variable named "welcome" and the value set to nothing. 2: Make a command for setting the welcome channel. Then put the following in your code/reply text: $setServerVar[welcome;$mentionedChannels[1]]
$argsCheck[>1;Please mention a channel!] Note: Servers will need to setup the channel they want the welcome message to send to. (by running a command with the code above). 3: Now replace your $onJoined[CHANNEL ID] in your welcome command trigger, with $onJoined[$getServerVar[welcome]] and your all set!
125.title: Advanced

126.body: Triggered when a user leaves the server.
126.title: $onLeave

127.body: a. Make the command trigger $onLeave[CHANNEL ID]. Channel IDs are not channel names! Please provide a channel ID . image b. Input your reply message/code. image c. Now you have a leave message! image
127.title: Example

128.body: 1: You must have at least version 1.17.9 of the app. 2: Go to Discord Developer Portal then open your bot's page and enable member intents. image image 3: Open the app and go to bot settings then enable member intents. image image image Note: Enabled intents in the app should reflect the intents enabled in Discord's dashboard. For example: If you have members intent enabled in Discord's dashboard then you should respectively enable them in the app (unless you don't want to use them at all). 4: Make sure $onLeave[CHANNEL ID] is inputted in the 'command trigger' field and has the correct usage. 5: Make sure your bot has permission to speak in the channel provided in $onLeave[]. 6: You can not use more that 1 $onLeave[] trigger per bot.
128.title: Troubleshooting

129.body:
Both free and premium users can use $onLeave[]. Also, all users can put $getServerVar[] within $onLeave[]. However, free users can not use $getServerVar[] outside of callbacks. If you own a global bot and want to make it so multiple different servers can use $onLeave[]. Follow these steps: 1: Make a variable named "leave" and the value set to nothing. 2: Make a command for setting the leave channel. Then put the following in your code/reply text: $setServerVar[leave;$mentionedChannels[1]]
$argsCheck[>1;Please mention a channel!] Note: Servers will need to setup the channel they want the leave message to send to. (by running a command with the code above). 3: Now replace $onLeave[CHANNEL ID] in your leave command trigger, with $onLeave[$getServerVar[leave]] and your all set!
129.title: Advanced

24.body: Slash commands is a new feature added by Discord. It let's users interact with your bot by typing /<command name>. preview
24.title: Slash Commands

25.body: Discord allows up to 50 slash commands. Before using slash commands you need to reinvite the bot with applications.commands scope. Creating/modifying/deleting slash command might take up to 1hr .
25.title: General information

26.body: Before we start, you need 1.18.8 version of the app or later.
26.title: Getting started

27.body: Open the app Pick your bot Open navigation drawer and then press "Server invites" Press the button with eye icon. Select Slash commands Go back Press "Add your bot to your server" Invite the bot to your server invite scopes
27.title: Reinviting the bot

28.body: Create or modify existing command Press the top-right icon Press "Enable slash command trigger" Fill in necessary data Save it slash command page
28.breadcrumbs: Slash commands » Creating a slash command
28.title: Creating a slash command

29.body: You can retrive a value from an option by simply using $message[<option name>]. If you want this function to work in a normal and slash command then you can use $message[<arg number>;<option name>]. Example message example code message example usage
29.breadcrumbs: Slash commands » Retriving value from options
29.title: Retriving value from options

31.body: In this section of wiki you will learn about some of the useful functions. Functions (as the name itself says) add extra functionality to your commands. They are heart and soul of your bot. Remember that functions start with $. For example $nomention or $ping.
31.title: Functions introduction

32.body: In this section of wiki you will learn about some of the useful functions. Functions (as the name itself says) add extra functionality to your commands. They are heart and soul of your bot. Remember that functions start with $. For example $nomention or $ping.
32.title: Functions introduction

33.body: This feature lets your bot to await for user's answer. Here's how the end result looks like: end result As you can see, the bot asks us to provide a number and then checks if provided value is a number.
33.breadcrumbs: BDScript » Awaited Commands » Awaited commands and functions
33.title: Awaited commands and functions

34.body: That's how is-number command looks like: is-number command $awaitFunc[test2] launches await command which is called test2.
34.title: is-number command

35.body: Here you can see the test2 awaited command: awaited command Have you noticed what's in the command's trigger? $awaitedCommand[test2;<numeric>] - the first argument is the command's name. In this case it's test2 . The second argument is a filter. <numeric> means that the awaited command expects only numbers . Here are currently available filters: <numeric> - only numbers are accepted <this/is/a/choice/filter> - one of the words separated by / is expected an empty filter - every word is accepted What happens if the filter doesn't match? Well, you can create a command which will be used instead.
35.title: Awaited command

36.body: error command As you can see, we are using $awaitedCommandError[test2] in the trigger. The first argument specifies the command's name. This command will only be used when the filter in the awaited command does not match user's response.
36.breadcrumbs: BDScript » Awaited Commands » Awaited error command
36.title: Awaited error command

37.body: Interprets commands conditionally. Every if statement starts with $if[condition] and has to end with $endif. $else is optional.
37.title: If Statements

38.body: Use $if[] to specify a block of code to be executed, if a specified condition is true. Use $else to specify a block of code to be executed, if the same condition is false. Use $else and $if[] to specify a new condition to test, if the first condition is false. Use $endif to end a if statement.
38.title: Breakdown

39.body:
$if[$username==kubastick] Hi Kuba!
$else Hi $username!
$endif $if[$getUserVar[money]>0] You're not broke
$endif $if[$username==noituri] $if[$message[<]==nice] Noit said nice $endif
$endif
39.title: Examples:

4.body: Added $httpGet[], $httpPost[], $httpPut[], $httpDelete[] and $httpPatch[] Improved overall caching Added $httpResult[] Made command execution faster
4.title: April

40.body: $if[] uses the format of: if x is related accordingly (based on the "sign") with y then the code below runs.
40.title: Explaination

41.body: == - Equal != - Not Equal < - Less Than > - Greater Than => - Greater Than Or Equal To <= - Less Than Or Equal To These signs could vary in meaning based on the order or intent of the if statement. If you are using text as your x and/or y, you can not use any other signs besides == and !=. However for numbers, you can use any sign shown in the above list.
41.title: Signs

43.body: BDFD doesn't have a specific function for else if blocks, but you can still do them by using $else and $if[]. The difference between $else and $else/$if[] is that else doesn't need a condition. Where as else if is still an if so it needs a condition. The main purpose for else if is to make it so only one if statement runs. Unlike regular if statements, the else if blocks should end with $else then start with another $if[]. Once you are done with your else if statements, close all of them with x number of $endifs (x = number of else if statements) at the bottom of the last else if statement.
43.title: Else If

44.breadcrumbs: BDScript » If Statements » Example Else If
44.title: Example Else If

46.body: This command was written by <@$authorID>! Expected output: This command was written by @user! Explanation: Discord uses this format <@USER_ID> to mention user. So for example let's say that $authorID is equal to 246604909451935745. If we'll use this <@$authorID> it will be replaced with <@246604909451935745> and discord will interpret this as a mention (@Noituri) .
46.title: Example command:

52.body: Command returns 'true' if a user has all of the provided permissions otherwise 'false' is returned.
52.title: $checkUserPerms

54.body: userID - The user that the bot checks the permissions for. perm1 - The first permission the bot checks for. perm2 and etc... - You can put as many permissions as you like, these fields are optional.
54.title: Breakdown

56.body:
If the user has ban permissions: true
If the user doesn't have ban permissions: false
56.title: Expected Output

57.body: A list of perms/permissions supported in the "perm1", "perm2", etc fields. • sendmessages • readmessages • createinstantinvite • admin • changenicknames • managenicknames • addreactions • ban • kick • manageroles • manageserver • managemessages • managechannels • manageemojis • mentioneveryone • readmessagehistory • attachfiles • tts • managewebhooks • embedlinks • externalemojis
57.title: Supported Permissions

58.body: There are three possible usages of the $dm command The first is: $dm This will send the message to the user that runs the command. The second is: $dm[] This will send the message to the first mentioned user. The third is: $dm[User ID;...] This will send the message to every user with given User ID. If the command fails to send the message, make sure the user allows dm messages from anyone. ⠀
58.title: $dm

63.body: Shows the delay between sent message and bot's response. The value of $ping is expressed in miliseconds.
63.title: $ping

64.body: Ping: $ping ms Expected output: Ping: 50 ms ⠀
64.title: Example command:

65.body: $roleInfo allows you to make a 'role info' command without using a bunch of different functions at once. The command returns info about the mentioned role.
65.title: $roleInfo

66.body: You can use the 'commands' below within it: {name} - Returns the role name {ID} - Return the role's ID {mentionable} - Sees if the role is mentionable by everyone {hoist} - Gets if a role is hoisted (displayed separately) {color} - Gives the role's color hex {position} - Returns the roles position on 'roles list' Usage: $roleInfo[commands/text here] ⚠️ You can not include $roleInfo[] in a command with a $description[] (because it makes one automatically).
66.title: Usage

67.title: Example Code

68.body:
Role Info
Name: RoleName
ID: RoleID
Mentionable?: true/false
Hoisted?: true/false
Color: hex-code
Position: position-number
68.title: Expected Output

7.body: Fixed the problem with statuses not showing up Fixed the issue with mentions not working Fixed loading bots from database Increased duration to 40 minutes for $deleteIn[], $editIn[], $editEmbedIn[], $replyIn[] Added if statements ($if[], $else, $endif) GuildID instead of everyone is now returned in $lowestRole[] and $highestRole[] Space commands have been removed (you can still use $alwaysReply) Added $channelTopic[] Fixed issues with streaming status Fixed the issue with tags/discriminators not working for $userID[] and $findUser[] Added $findChannel[] and $channelExists[] Added $userJoined[] and $userJoinedDiscord[]
7.title: January

70.body: $serverInfo allows you to make a 'server info' command without using a bunch of different functions at once. It returns info about the current server.
70.title: $serverInfo

71.body: You can use the 'commands' below within it: {name} - Returns the server name {region} - Returns the server region {emoji} - Lists the server's emojis in a list {owner} - Gives the owner's username {ID} - Gets the guild ID {verificationLvl} - Returns the server verification level {large} - Finds out if a server is considered 'large' Usage: $serverInfo[commands/code here;(optional)yes/no] ⚠️ You can not include $serverInfo[] in a command with a $description[] (because it makes one automatically).
71.title: Usage

72.title: Example Code

73.body:
Server Name: Server-Name
Region: Server-Region
Owner: Server-Owner
Server ID: Guild-ID
Verify Level: low/medium/high/very high
Emojis: List-Of-Emojis
Large Server?: true/false
73.title: Expected Output

74.body: $serverInfo[commands/code here] can work fine on its own, but automatically the bot returns the server icon in the thumbnail is the yes/no argument is left empty. Disable Server Icon Thumbnail - $serverInfo[commands/code here;no] Enable Server Icon Thumbnail - $serverInfo[commands/code here;yes] OR $serverInfo[commands/code here]
74.title: What's The yes/no Argument?

76.body: With Slowmode enabled in a channel, it'll limit the number of messages a user is able to send in a channel based on a timed cooldown. $slowmode[] is used to change a channel's slowmode using a bot.
76.title: $slowmode

78.body: Channel ID - The channel in the which the slowmode is being modified in. Delay - The change in delay (in seconds). E.g: 1s, 180s, 5s, 3s, etc.
78.title: Breakdown

79.body:
$nomention
$slowmode[$mentionedChannels[1;yes];$message[1]]
Slowmode changed to $message[1]!
$argsCheck[>1;:x: Incorrect Usage! Example: `!slowmode 5s`] Expected Output Slowmode changed to ...
*slowmode gets modified*
79.title: Example Command

80.body: If you would like to disable slowmode, use 0 or 0s as the "delay" argument.
80.title: Disabling Slowmode

81.body: Slowmode delay can't be set over 6 hours/21,600 seconds. In order for the bot to run $slowmode[] successfully, it needs Manage Channels permissions.
81.title: Limitations/Warnings

82.body: $userInfo[] allows you to make a 'user info' command without using a bunch of different functions at once. The bot returns info about the mentioned user.
82.title: $userInfo

83.body: You can use the 'commands' below within it: {username} - Returns the user's username {ID} - Gets the users ID {BOT} - Checks if the user is a bot {discriminator} - Gets the user's discriminator Usage: $userInfo[commands/code here] ⚠️ You can not include $userInfo[] in a command with a $description[] (because it makes one automatically).
83.title: Usage

85.body:
User Info
Username: Username
User ID: User-ID
Bot?: true/false
Discriminator: four-digit-number
85.title: Expected Output

86.body: Returns date when given user joined the server. You can also give your own date format.
86.title: $userJoined

9.body: Timezones in $time[] has been fixed Updated discord API version Added Competing presence Added $botLeave[] Fix for $getLeaderboardValue[] Added userID option to reset user var Added serverID option to $serverOwner Added $premiumExpireTime
9.title: December

90.body: The format allows you to customize the date format. Monday = Day January = Month 3:04 = Time 2006 = Year 2 = Day Of The Month
90.title: Format

91.body: $userJoined[$authorID;January 2 (Monday), 2006 at 3:04] would return Month DayOfTheMonth (Day), Year at Time.
91.title: Format Example

92.body: Returns the date when given user created their Discord account. You can also give your own date format.
92.title: $userJoinedDiscord

96.body: The format option allows you to customize the date format. Monday = Day January = Month 3:04 = Time 2006 = Year 2 = Day Of The Month
96.title: Format

97.body: $userJoinedDiscord[$authorID;January 2 (Monday), 2006 at 3:04] would return Month DayOfTheMonth (Day), Year at Time.
97.title: Format Example

98.body: Bot Designer for Discord allows you to use JavaScript (ES2015) . Discord's API is not fully supported yet but there will be more extensive support in the future. (NOTE: Callbacks don't support JavaScript at the moment)
98.title: JavaScript

99.body: message - string value. It contains message written by the user. commandPrefix - string value. It contains name of the used command. authorId - string value. It contains ID of the user that executed that command. channelId - string value. It contains ID of the channel where the command was used. userMentions - array of string values. It contains user mentions (pings) . roleMentions - array of string values. It contains role mentions (pings) .
99.breadcrumbs: JavaScript » Available objects in the commands:
99.title: Available objects in the commands:
